Fields.DialogueText: She'd have a lot to talk about with Kirishima.

Fields.MenuText: A destroyer *Belle,* remember. And no, we still don't know.
I don't believe it either. But we don't even know what "it" is.
Unknown. August has been glued to the radio, but he hasn't heard any of the usual Morgana chatter.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmm. Consistent with Ekbom syndrome, but it's never been observed in Belles.
Well, looks like we got here too late for whatever.
Lucky him. It's bad news keeping a man on that junk.
What's the Belle say? Our Belle, I mean, not the rabid one. Apologies for the lack of medical accuracy there, but--
She's adamant that it's not a  Morgana trick. This is one of ours, but... off. Mixed signals, she said.
A destroyer did *this?*
God Almighty.
If only.
I'll say. We could comb through the debris for weeks before the scrap ran dry.
Is that all you think about?
Konechno nyet. Sometimes I think about retiring to the shores of the Caspian, drink in one hand, the other--
I take it back. I like you better greedy.
Doctor, there you are. I thought you were below.
But there's a cold chopping through our refugee VIPs like wheat. Greta doesn't need me to make tea and hand out limes.
No survivors to be below for, I'm afraid.
Never a good sign when Belles get cryptic.
Well, we're going to keep looking. We still haven't found our damsel in distress.
You're not wrong. All we know is that there's a Belle-active destroyer in the area raving about being covered in bugs.
Most things haven't. But I'm *reasonably certain* it's not any human psychosis.
Gotta start somewhere. Didn't that one French carrier have gremlins?
Is that what they're calling it now?
It would have cost you *nothing* to keep that to yourself.
Consider it an investment.
Now's not the time for gossip.
Ha! Is the color of the sky gossip? The ocean? How about the weather?
Or just in time.
To Herr Cassel, maybe it is. I don't think he's left the radio room since--
Wait! There she is.
Good lord, she's listing like a damn almanac.
We should get alongside her and heave to. We'll board and see if--
NO!
August, what the--
Kapitän, if you value your life - if you value *everyone's* lives - you'll stay away from that ship.
What about the lifeboats?
She's sending out lifeboats. Looks like I'll have some work after all.
About time. I was starting to think you'd--
She says they're fine. *She* isn't.
And "she" is...
Demanding we put her underwater if we know what's good for us. Begging, really.
... Oh. Right. She's Santa Catarina. Brazilian. Destroyer. N'abend.
*FLOP*
Good catch, Captain.
Hope he likes tea.
So that's a no on the salvage operation, I suppose.
Get below. We're not the only ones who smell blood in the water.
@BATTLE
Doesn't she?
She deputized some of the healthy ones. She speaks the language, anyway.
Come to take in the view of a nautical crime scene, Enoch? Lugin was just trying to guess how many ships an insane Belle has to kill to get wreckage like this.
Whoa! August?
He's heavier than he looks. August? August, you with us?
Doc, can we get him a bed and some of the good stuff?
*ALARM*
Keep your shirt on. Kirishima's not here anymore.
Right. Well, first things last. Who do we know that speaks Portuguese?
Nobody on this side of the Atlantic, I'm afraid. But my friends in Lisbon should have friends...
Thousands... everywhere, crawling, buzzing... flying south, always to the south...
Beruhige dich. You've been out for a while.
Doctor... Kapitän! Where's the--
Quit stirring the pot.
You quit poisoning it. Ain't exactly a secret that that girl's caught a fever from Clever Hans.
Talking of poison, that's the tea. Grab it before it burns this time, won't you?
Wouldn't be a problem if you'd let me spike it.
Hush. You're not getting your suture kit back until you outgrow that sort of thing.
How is he?
He's fine, Kapitän. Wondering why he's woken up in a cot instead of in his chair.
You were carried in here after listening to those witches yammer for three days straight. I'm surprised you weren't bleeding from the ears.
It wasn't the Morganas. Not... not toward the end.
I trust, but I could use some details. We-
You go talk to them the way you know how.
@BATTLE
It just seemed impolite to have the refugees serving themselves.
We've had to make port more frequently, but we've got the food situation under control.
Just stay right there. I'll be back with some more water.
Now really, Capitaine. Is that any way to greet a colleague?
Savary. Don't tell me you haven't been sleeping either.
You're worried that the Brazilians are going to think you've gone rogue.
Sorry. I've been spending too much time with August, I guess. Haven't been able to get to the bottom of the whole Santa Catarina... thing.
Well, we'll need a better excuse when the Brazilian Navy asks us why we put one of their only Belles out of commission.
Either way, the Morganas had already killed her. We just made it... easier for her. Trust me on that.

Fields.MenuText: Exile, hell. Europe isn't the only front.
Maybe it'll show them we mean business.
There had to have been another way.

Fields.DialogueText: At least down here we're in the way of only one invasion.
The Morganas or the League?
Whatever it was, Capitaine, it was on the other side of that island the Morganas destroyed.
Not a good look for our first day in exile, though.
I don't know. They heard what was going on for themselves, at least - August says he was able to patch her through to Natal. Briefly.
Either. Both. We need something good to come out of this.
We still don't even know if it was the Morganas.
Who else is in the business of stripping islands for raw materials?
Once we figure out what "this" is.
They can't all come up in the Faroes. Look, take my advice: just bide your time.
Right, poor choice of words. We don't know *which* of them it was. And I really don't want to sail right into another emergence event so far from League waters.
Oui. We've been put on the shelf, as it were, so we might as well dust while we're up here. Just until Europe remembers it's hopeless without us.
No.
But I am making a case to worry about different things. Why, take me, par exemple. I've busied myself making the refugees comfortable. Some of them have been willing to talk.
You're not making a strong case not to worry.
And when I recount their testimony in the bestselling account of our war effort...
Sounds like a job for your contacts. Listen, if it wasn't clear, I appreciate what you're doing down here.
And that starts with securing some better rations for the people we pulled out of the path of the invader.
Well, I like my control with fresh fruit.
I'd rather they describe a capitaine who was too busy cleaning house to brood about who's invading who thousands of miles away.
The--
Apart from our very badly overworked Belle.
It's the second Pará-class they've lost this year since Mato Grosso last month. But at least they know the story.
... So we did sink her? Santa Catarina?
Yeah. Yeah, once we'd rescued her crew, she turned her guns on us herself. If she was at all in control, she turned us into a suicide weapon. If she was just rabid-
Dammit.
*ALARM*
I honestly don't know what I expected.
Perhaps a vacation from the matters of the heart?
Arigato. Just put it over there with the rest.
Okay, this should be the last crate.
Actually, the crew of the Santa Catarina wanted it kept separate.
What's so special about this one?
They said it wasn't good to put it near human things. Sounds like Morgana stuff, if you ask me.
All right! Box number seven. Looks like we've got...
Clothes. Kuso.
Superstitious enough to want it in its own box, but *not* to avoid picking it up. That's a very specific level of fear.
Which calls for gloves.
Well, have fun with your witchery. Think I'll find me a nice inland bar.
Nine kilometers.
Hmm?
Whatever.
Ahem. No intellectual curiosity in our yeoman, hm? For moving crates, though, there's nobody I'd rather have on my side.
Hmph. If he's so spooked, why did he even touch it?
Let's say you're a sailor with nothing to his name but the clothes on his back.
You've got a little money now and again, but eventually you drink it. You spend a night with a lady in port, but you're at sea the next day.
What's the one thing that can't slip through your fingers? Why, a story!
You're telling me that our crate-mover-in-chief was hoping something would pop out of the box and eat him because it would make a good story.
And why not? A good story gets the drink flowing, starts conversations that lead all sorts of interesting places with interesting people.
Oh, I've got one!
Once upon a time there was an accomplished mechanic who got stuck on inventory duty after a close encounter.
Try as she might, she couldn't find anything interesting. After sifting through piles and piles of clothes and rations, she died of boredom and was buried in one of the crates. The end.

Fields.MenuText: I seem to recall that you volunteered.
Sounds like there's nothing to fence, Orest.
August should be back in his quarters. If you're bored, I think he'd appreciate a visit.

Fields.DialogueText: You wound me, Kapitan! Our refugees get the friends-and-family discount for these fine articles.
Hey, Kanchou. Oops, looks like I miscounted everything. I'd better start from the beginning. While remaining in port.
Come on, what's the worst that could happen?
Ease up, Kapitan. You're making her blush.
A-allergic reaction. It's so smoky around here.
How curious! When you drink, do you turn blue?
You just might find out if there's nothing in this crate. Help me with it, won't you?
Not until I appraise this stuff. Help me with the lid?
Urusai. I can't... get this... lid...
Grab hold, Kapitan. You and me and the cute one. One... two...
Three!
... Lugin-san, you had your eye on Miller. Do you remember him struggling with this?
Perhaps it is a very dense compass.
It's empty except for... a compass?
Are you suggesting I have experience pretending to pull my weight?
Looks evil, all right. If it's iridescent or rusting--
Nine kilometers?
The range on Santa Catarina's guns. Give or take a few hundred meters. We still don't know if she was... all there.
You're a murder boat connoisseur!
Trying to be. It's the girl *on* the ship that puzzles me.
The late Belle with the bug problem? Da, da. Our best source for that is probably--
*GLARE*
--taking a well-earned nap.
Wait, Kirishima--
Relax, Kanchou, I'm wearing gloves.
... Hmm. It's not moving. No matter which way I turn it...

Fields.MenuText: Blast. Keep an eye on it, would you?

Fields.DialogueText: Haaaiii. Well, it doesn't look like it points at the Morganas. Or *these* Morganas.
How about to your heart's desire?
"Throwing you into the sea" isn't a direction.
Ah, young love.
@BATTLE
--then it's probably Morgana.
Both.

Fields.MenuText: I think one of the Santa Catarina boys signed on. He might know more about this.

Fields.DialogueText: The one that keeps stalking around with the flyswatter? Something tells me he's... distracted.
Well, we're all about to be distracted. I'll keep the Morganas out of port while you finish up.
Got a minute?
Sure. Those the Belle intel reports?
Yep. You know, if I didn't know better I'd be tempted to run these by August.

Fields.MenuText: Not a chance. He's still recovering from the Santa Catarina incident.
Have you been able to get anything out of him?
Let's get right to it. No telling when we'll be interrupted.

Fields.DialogueText: Never is.
Let's see... Conte di Cavour's reporting in. Says Somalia's finally clearing up. The Regia Marina even discussed downgrading the front.
Just discussed?
Yep. I don't think they want to take any chances after that Vanity thing.
Who builds a palace on the bottom of the sea?
It's nuts. You know, they say you could feel it in Sardinia when that thing went up. Whatever she had cooking down there, it was the right move to blow it.
He'll only talk to you. Says he'd prefer not to inflict it on anyone else.
That man's too noble for his own good.
Privileged information I get, but I wonder if it wouldn't be better if the doc just stuck him in a coma until you get an evening free. Nobody should have to carry that knowledge around alone.
If you say so.
And anyway, I can't care about what she said right this minute. Between that, the compass, the refugees...
Honestly, the refugees are my first priority. The sooner we get them off the ship, the better.
You'd think he'd have more visitors. Kirishima at least...
You're out of the loop, Cap. Let's leave it at that.
Well, loop me back in. What do the Belles say?
It was a good thing what you did, Captain. Don't get it twisted.
It got us kicked out of Europe.
You think you can fit everyone on this boat that needs fitting?
Nah. And anyway, people listen to you. Not just about Morganas. I'd bet you anything there'll be fewer Jews in Poland than Hitler expected to find.
I just hope they have a better time relocating than ours are having. Well, never mind. Let's get on with it.
They're not giving up on Somalia, though.
Never. Madagascar's their big white whale - they figure that's an easier potential redoubt than Socotra. French reports corroborate that.
Hmm. If my name's still mud in Europe in a couple months, that might be our next front.
On that subject. De Ruyter's been following Morgana behavior in the North Sea now that they've settled into something resembling a pattern.
You remember the Willemsbrug?
From the Rotterdam raid, yeah. The bridge that got eaten.
Well, De Ruyter's no mathematician, but she swears she's seen more Willemsbrug steel in North Sea Morganas than they should have been able to cannibalize.
That's what she thought. But then she bagged a Cowardice who'd built herself a new stern half out of that stuff.
Okay, that specific shade aside... If you've seen one piece of scrap metal, I assume you've seen them all.
Now, I knew me a girl once in Amsterdam. I still keep the only postcard she sent me once I lit out east. That bridge is on that postcard. It's got real distinctive crests.
I've seen it up close. I'd know that ornamentation anywhere. And sure enough, it showed up in De Ruyter's photographs - embossed in Cowardice's stolen steel, more often than on the bridge itself.
So they're not just stealing stuff. They're reproducing it. But we knew that already.
They're not just learning, Captain. They're *forging.* *Building.* They don't just appear - well, not *just.*
We knew that they were trying their hand at extracting oil and minerals. Bulldog proved they were repairing in the Gulf of Riga a while back.
This is different. Their collective memory - that stuff Lexington was experimenting with - is incorporating our methods, our symbols, our materiel. And it's all being manufactured somewhere.
And they've got a big enough sample size to play favorites. Not just building back, not just adapting, but getting creative.
There's no other reason to keep the ornamentation.
Unless you're Avarice.
Only if it's real gold.
So they've got some headquarters - or HQs, plural - that we haven't found yet.
Or they're trying to scale up personal operations *to* get to that point.
And here we are with vague instructions to patrol Brazil.
Mahan.
That's a big ocean. Like, Hawaii, the Galapagos, Micronesia... ?
Yes.
Phew. Well, stash that in my quarters and get to your station. It sure as hell isn't going anywhere.
*THUD*
As for the bulk of it... based primarily on American and Japanese recon and after-actions, she's put together a dissertation on Morgana tactics in the Pacific.
I might have known.
@BATTLE
Seeing as he's our unofficial expert on shipgirl nonsense and all. After False Hope--
The first twenty or so pages summarize the situation at the Panama Canal. Apparently there's a quarantine, but relatively little Morgana activity.
What about that last folder?
Dehydration, headaches, whatever else - both doctors have told me to leave him alone.
Never mind. Let's get on with it.
Hmm. Running out of options.
I swear that woman's a Belle and just hiding it. The way she gets into all my usual spaces...
... In a medical sense, or--
Gah! Announce yourself, why don't you?
Monsieur le docteur. Doing some housekeeping?
Of course I am. I've got to run a clean operation.
Too true. Got to find a place for that medicinal condenser coil.
Excuse me?
Oh, come off it. I didn't spend *all* of university studying, you know.
Of course not. All right, damn it, what's your silence worth?
What on earth would you need it for? The Captain deals with far more harebrained things from the Belles every other day.
It ain't the Captain I'm worried about. It's Carrie Nation down in sick bay.
Who?
Not important. Van Geffen. She's cleaned out my stash three times since Armistice Day.
Such a busybody.
I'm glad someone aboard's got sense.
Sense enough to want in on your little moonshine operation.
You're a journalist, you're a yeoman, you're a nurse, you're a moonshiner...
And when things get slow and ponderous, as they frequently do south of the big European war, I'm a social drinker.
Well, I hope you like white lightning.
Why settle? It just so happens that the Capitaine has signed off on some off-the-books requisitions while we're here in Brazil.
Who do you know that speaks Portuguese?
I know enough to order a caipirinha. And a certain Russian exile tells me that you've got limes enough.
That boy's going to be the death of us one day.
There are worse fates. We'll talk.
@BATTLE
You're sleeping through the night, I heard.
Against my better judgment.

Fields.MenuText: We're not going to beat the Morganas with insomnia, you know.
Bad dreams?
Better judgment, hell. If you hadn't bolted above I would have pulled you out of the radio room myself.

Fields.DialogueText: Sloth, maybe.
And you're up to joking, too. See, you'll be back on your feet before you know it.
The kind you remember.
I wish I could say I would have resisted.
No, you don't. You were transcribing madness round the clock. I flipped through some of your reports.
You'll have to excuse my shorthand.
August, some of it was written in blood.
Silly me. I misplaced my ink.
Can you tell me about them?
I wish I could have heard her as she--
I doubt I could make sense of them.
Well, we'd have to start with your radio transcripts.
I need to sit down with them and--
Look, let's start with this world before we get to Hell. I've been in contact with the Brazilians.
You did good bringing them in on Santa Catarina's broadcast. We would have had no end of trouble if there were only our word to go on.
Half of Europe thinks we're working for the other half. I figured we ought to get out ahead of that sort of thing.
So what did she want from us? I've never heard of a Belle asking to be sunk before.
It's not so much her as it was... something she'd stumbled upon. Or something her battle group had that she knew had to go down.
Call it an infection. Call it an infestation. But it was unmistakably Morgana in origin, it had... chosen her, or stuck to her. And the only thing for it was to burn it out.
I don't envy you the task of sitting down and parsing all this. But, Kapitän...
It's better that she's gone. We have more time. She told me so herself.
More time for what?
To prepare for the next one.
... I'm sorry. I can't--
I'll bring you something lighter when you wake up. Didn't Kirishima have some cowboy comics?
Buck Rogers. You're thinking of Yūbari.
Right. Just... take your time. It's good to have you with us, August.
Vielen Dank.
Tolerable.
August. How's your head?
Ano... hmph. Nothing.
You'll get some strange looks waving that Morgana scrap around.
Not so much. I think people are starting to take this stuff for granted. Weird, huh?
... Anywhere else, sure. But, now that you mention it, I think *we're* all used to things we'd rather not be.
Hmm.
Something on your mind?
You're a navigator, right?
Try to be.
Can you make any sense of this?
Well, if the compass only points one way, you've got yourself a busted compass.
Brilliant, Columbus-kun.
But you don't think it's busted.
Well, compasses are supposed to point north. This doesn't, and it's not pointing to the magnetic south either. Not quite.
So if it wasn't built by human hands, it couldn't have had a human purpose.
So there's a reason it's pointing south-ish. We just don't know it yet.
... Hmm. You grew up in San Francisco.
Haaai?
Well, I've never been west of the Mississippi.
You wouldn't have missed much. It all kind of runs together once you hit desert.
Nah. There was too much going on in Alabama. Europe came next.
And I learned something in Europe that you probably learned in Frisco.
Spanish?
Heh. Un poquito.
No. It's all those cathedrals and whatnot. They've got centuries of history we don't back in the States. Architecturally, anyway.
Notre Dame ain't just a church. It's a point of reference. Ask some people - me, for instance, in the autumn of 1935 - and they'd tell you "Oh, yeah, just turn south a few blocks once you get there."
Favorite bar?
Book club. But you'd never know it if you weren't in it, or didn't know someone who was.
Sort of like the Golden Gate Bridge. You could just see it from where I lived.
So what you're saying is we just have to think like a Morgana.
Lord only knows where Santa Catarina's crew got this thing. But I say we follow it.
Well, why didn't Santa Catarina?
I wish I had an answer for you. But I think we both know who might.
... Please tell me you meant the Morganas.
Let's live to find out.
@BATTLE
Damn it, I know he's up to something.
Trouble in paradise?
Kapitän, you know him better than I do. Where's he keeping his devil's drink?

Fields.MenuText: I don't know him *that* well.
If it's not interfering with his work, it's none of our business.
I doubt he can hide it from you for long.

Fields.DialogueText: Quatsch. You're the Kapitän. The tomfoolery stops with you.
He's no lush, I'll give him that. But that's all he gets.
Try as he might. That cold's certainly keeping us busy.
Assuming there is any.
I suppose that doesn't leave this room.
Seems you know me better than he does, too.
It's nothing more serious, is it?
Seasonal. Latitudinal. Lord knows these folks needed a change of scenery, but they're not taking to it as well as they'd like. Or I'd like, for that matter.
In the meantime, that cold's just about made the rounds of the refugees.
There's always something. If it weren't for me, that August boy would still be writing that letter to Satan or whatever it was.
Santa Catarina.
Right. I've got enough to worry about, what with the cold and all.
Well, it seems like you're on top of it.
Damn straight. Now shoo, visiting hours are over.
Right. Keep up the good work.
That was close.
Don't jinx it. Now, what's this I hear about contraband?
Well, I remember it like it was yesterday. Thrice yesterday, in fact...
But nothing human built this. I'm pretty sure.
"... Responded to a distress signal southwest of Fernando de Noronha. Population penal, thought eradicated after investigation."
"The origin of the signal was Santa Catarina, a manifested Pará-class destroyer in Brazilian service."
"SC repeatedly complained of 'crawling,' 'buzzing,' other sensations and sounds reminiscent of insect infestation. As such..."
"... she asked that she be terminated. When INPF forces failed to oblige, she responded aggressively."
"Her request was then granted. Refer to transcript in which--"
Ugh.
Headache?
After-action report.
Mind if I take a look?
Bottom of the page.
Hmm. The voice *is* a mite passive.

Fields.MenuText: Which I've never been accused of being.
It's better than "We proceeded to murder a Belle."
I don't think there's ever been anyone who's had to do something like this.

Fields.DialogueText: August was getting close.
I made my decision. I don't regret the process.
And next time you make one like it, it'll be all the quicker.
Well, then nobody can tell you you screwed it up.
It's a little more complicated than that.
You try telling that to *anyone* not in the know.
Come on. You're *the* Belle Captain. You wouldn't hurt these girls if Avarice paid you.
Look. What do we know so far? Work back from today.
We're getting our story straight about Santa Catarina's death.
And what did she tell us?
Ultimately? Because she wanted us to.
And why'd you do it?
We sank her. I sank her.
And what happened to her?
... Still working on it. August hasn't yet sorted out everything he's recorded.
My advice, Captain?
Wait until he figures out what the hell he heard.
That way lies madness enough without trying to fill in the blanks yourself.
You talk to the Belle about it?
She's just as in the dark as I am. Except she sensed... how'd she describe it?
It'll have to wait.
@BATTLE
*ALARM*
Mmm. Just breathe in that sirloin.
How on earth did you swing this?
Well, I wired Lisbon while we were in Natal. I know someone who knows someone in the Corporative Chamber.
I called in a favor over there, and he called in a favor over here. Apparently some Uruguayans downcountry were desperate for a contract. Isn't modern communication grand?
Can't complain. At least the Morganas haven't gotten to the transatlantic cables.
I've a theory about that.
Oh?
I think if their goal was extermination, it'd be foolish to let us speak to each other. How long has Venom been stalking the northern Brazilian coast?
Their short-term goal.
How long, Capitaine?
Since the war started. Belém still hasn't started the Marajó ferry back up.
So I hear. Well, the Morganas may be evil, but they're also resourceful.
They wouldn't throw away anything they thought they could use against us. That's our telegraphs, our radio, our newspapers...
Newspapers?
Never say never. It's no secret that the big powers have gotten offers of one kind or another.
Yeah, Belfast's mentioned that before. I try not to think about it.
There's one comfort. They're not capable of taking us on without turning us on each other.

Fields.MenuText: If only that weren't so easy.
Or they'd prefer not to.
That's what separates us from them. Hope.

Fields.DialogueText: Hope and unimpeachable taste in beef.
While I don't disagree... Look. About that.
I appreciate you securing this steak for the crew and the refugees. It's good for morale all around.
None of that, now. They're bad enough without building them up in your head.
I admit they picked a good time to invade.
But history is full of warring peoples coming together to vanquish a greater enemy.
Why, just look at our medical crew!
The Doctor started a rumor that van Geffen was a Morgana.
Sounds playful. What was she supposed to be called?
If I told you, I'd be court-martialed.
There are worse rivalries out there, Capitaine. Focus on the one between your teeth and your steak.
I suppose no amount of theorizing could have predicted the army of evil teddy bears.
Then let's just take these things as they come. Occasionally you might luck into some delicious steak.
But you realize I've got to keep a record of this for Command.
I'm sure the Belle doesn't mind pitching in.
Right. But I'm of the opinion - and Command would likely tend to agree - that we can't keep putting ashore each week for two hundred extra head worth of rations.
Make no mistake, Capitaine, I raise the matter with my new people in Brazil whenever the conversation slows.
Natal said no. Fortaleza said no. Recife said no. I've been trying to raise the issue with the Brazilian government, but I haven't been able to secure a state sponsor from anywhere in Europe.
For fear they'll be accused of trafficking German citizens.
Schrödinger's Jews, it seems. Both citizens and not, until the Federal Foreign Office takes a hard look.
Keep looking.
August! So good to see you up and about.
Glad to be back. You're framing it wrong.
Oh?
Shame. This steak's delicious.
@BATTLE
Don't make it an appeal to humanity or charity or what have you.
That... might actually turn some heads. Why didn't I think of that?
The Captain's right about the logistics question. The more time we spend restocking, the less time we spend blasting Nixen. Nobody - citizen or country - wants to be responsible for that.
And frankly, it'd free up more space in the hold for munitions.
Well, nobody's perfect.
Because you think of people as people.
Duty calls. You'd better take cover.
And just when we were sitting down to a lovely lunch.
*ALARM*
Oh, he would have agreed with the current approach. I'm sure of it. He would have said the common people had no need for information because people like *him* would make the big decisions.
Though that's not at all how he would have chosen to live *his* life - just waiting to be told what was safe to know. Not when there was a chance to achieve something better.
A moment?
Hmm?
I won't bother you if you don't want to be bothered. Not long. It's just... well.
Well, the world's ending.
How are you?
We both live there, so I can relate.
And people like me are being rounded up and executed. Which you'd think wouldn't be at odds with the whole apocalypse *thing,* but there it is.
And while both of these things are going on, we find ourselves in the part of the world that's maybe least relevant to solving them.
Outside of a desert, anyway.
Sorry. You don't want to hear this.
I fancy myself a journalist, August. So whether I want to be on the front lines of the most pressing stories of our age is quite beside the point.
It's not a question of professional duty, Marie. It's a question of sanity.
Belles... Morganas... I think you'll find that the fewer people have to deal with it all, the better.
Truly? Kirishima's quite taken with the--
So she's told me. That's unfortunate for her.
The thing is, you weren't there for the... for the review of what we found on the Hope. Neither of you were. You didn't see what she showed us.
If you want to gaze back into this particular abyss, be my guest.
But there are only so many Belles to keep it from spilling over into our world. Bertie actually never had a chance to weigh in on what should be kept secret, but-
Someone's got to follow the breadcrumbs.
No, I don't. In your fairy tale, the breadcrumb trail leads to an oven. Or have you forgotten?
When you're behind, maximize risk, I suppose.
You suppose correctly.
But you're not the only one at risk here.
No need to drive the point home. We'll continue this conversation, August.
She was called False Hope for a reason, Savary.
I doubt we agree on what that is.
@BATTLE
So what was it?
You know I can't tell you. It's so top secret I'm probably in trouble just for having nightmares about it.
Well, it's not fair that they're demanding that of you. Keeping some secrets can just cost too much.
Stop using your journalism powers on me.
I'm being serious. I have a history of living with big and terrible secrets, August. They cost me years, they poisoned my life, and they got out in the end anyway.
My father was a product of this... culture of secrecy. I'm not at all sure that it's good for the world that he was here to infect you with it when False Hope came along.
Wait. Are you... saying you had a problem with your father? Because literally no one on this ship had noticed.
But you're trying to deflect. Tu sais que j'ai raison.
Ha! Bon, a point to you.
We do. The INPF does. Journalists are a whole other question.
I think you'll find it's what the profession is all about, August.
Hmm. Waning crescent.
Taking into account the prevailing wind, we have...
Nothing. Well, cross that off the list.
Konbanwa, Doctor-san.
Kirishima. What are you doing out at this hour?
Damn it all. Knew I should have made two--
Eliminating variables.
That that evil machine from Santa Catarina?
It's *supposed* to be a compass.
But it's only pointing south-southwest.
So what's south-southwest?
I had that same question. But I figured I should make sure there's nothing else affecting it.
So far I've determined it doesn't respond to heat, cold, the time of day, half of the moon's phases, it isn't magnetic, it doesn't corrode metal or rot fruit...
I knew there was a lime missing.
And no amount of blunt force will crack it.
Well, that's a fascinating project. I'll leave you to it.
Speaking of fascinating projects...
Oh, this stuff? Weather equipment. Don't even worry about it.
Savary-san told me you'd say something like that. And that you'd swear you were absolutely not building a still.
I swear, the minute I see that woman--
I think she assumed I wanted in on your little drinking club.
How old are you, exactly?
Old enough!
Of course you are. Here, help me pack this stuff in that lifeboat.
You know, while we're on the subject of experiments...
First glass is yours. Hell, take three.
@BATTLE
What a mess.
I'd heard Brazil was going through it.
It just doesn't add up.
How's that?
They can't be everywhere at once.
... You *were* there on the first of September, weren't you?
You know what I mean. Even the Morganas are finite. Otherwise we'd never be rid of them, no matter where we went.
Let's say you're in charge of the Morganas. Where would you attack to do the most damage to our shipping?
Well, if I'm over in this hemisphere... the Panama Canal.
And what did you tell me about the Panama Canal during the briefing the other day?
It's not a hot zone. Well, not as hot as we'd otherwise expect.

Fields.MenuText: I'd like to believe that we're in a general ebb.
Still. You'd think they'd put us somewhere more pivotal.
Then why aren't we in one?

Fields.DialogueText: Mahan says the US and Mexico are taking the Panama Canal extremely seriously. It might just be a numbers game.
So say we all.
Brazil's feeling the heat, from what I hear.
I know. And it's only a matter of time before the public gets its hands on the Santa Catarina story.
Worried?
Hell no. The Brazilian Navy knows we're on the up-and-up.
Just... keep your ear to the ground while we're in port, okay? The last thing we need is another Constitution.
Oh, don't you worry. Orest's been talking my ear off about that Carnival stuff. You should see the Belle costumes.
Oh, boy.
Even a couple of Morgana ones. Hoo-wee. Some of those newspaper photos...
Maybe leave those out next time you lend me the paper.
Of course, Captain.
Thanks.
... Enoch.
Where's he been?
Captain?
You said you talked to Orest.
I did.
Oh! Phil Nowlan just died.
*Who?*
Ugh. This interview's over. I'm going to get to the bottom of this if it kills me.
@BATTLE
You were using a Morgana artifact of unknown provenance as a *paperweight?*
You all know why you're here.
You spoke to Lugin about the salvage from Santa Catarina. Has any of it gone missing?
Ie, he wasn't interested. It was mostly boring stuff like clothes and rations. But there was that compass...
Where's that compass now?
My quarters. I was using it as a paperweight.
As far as I know - maybe as far as any of us know - Lugin has been missing, at least since the 3rd.
I don't know why. But each of you spoke with him the day of the Santa Catarina incident and the days immediately after.
I don't know if these things are related. But that's my frame of reference. I need yours.
Doctor. You spoke to Lugin on the 4th. What's the last thing you remember talking to him about?
He draws - drew - Buck Rogers?
Anything else *important* I need to know?
Anything else I need to know?
He was mighty curious about some of my equipment - solution bags and the like. I brushed it off as youthful curiosity.
You brushed it off as youthful curiosity.
His word for it.
Lugin's word.
Look, I'd had a few fingers of whiskey with my tea, all right? I was off the clock. I think Taylor was on duty that night.
And then you started noticing some missing equipment.
Just out of the spares. Haven't needed it, thankfully. I guess he figured I wouldn't miss it.
Indeed. Kirishima.
Kanchou?
Well, my research notes would have gone everywhere otherwise.
Not that I need them with the way it whispers its secrets to me.
Gah! Only joking, Kanchou!
Enoch, grab her.
Hai, Kanchou. Sorry, Kanchou.
Enoch, don't grab her. Kirishima, this is serious. Stop messing around.
You got it.
But as for you, Enoch - you know Lugin better than anyone aboard.
Yeah. Hell, I was there the day he talked his way onto the Lune.
Right.
He hadn't indicated any subversive behavior? Recently, I mean.
No more than usual. I think he's been antsy since the whole Finland thing. Who wouldn't be?
We clear?
Hai. I think Kanchou trusts us too much or too little.
Real funny. Any word from van Geffen?
No, and I'm surprised the Captain didn't call her in here. Sometimes I think she's too good at keeping her head down.
You worry about her?
Down where it damn well belongs, wise guy. I'm just glad Lugin got to her first...
Well, one thing's for sure...

Fields.MenuText: One of you is lying.
All of you know something that you aren't telling me.
We're dealing with a potentially massive leak.

Fields.DialogueText: Hmph.
Thus far nothing's disappeared except some medical equipment. But there'll be hell to pay if I find documents or munitions missing. And let's not even get started on the Belle.
I can't prove it, but I will.
Thank goodness the Belle's been keeping mum. Some of those girls are worse liars than you are.
... You know, Enoch, none of this would have happened if you hadn't spilled the beans.
All I said was I'd talked to Orest! Nothing about when or where or what about.
I can't prove it, but I will.

Fields.MenuText: Enoch, I hope you're not putting a friend before our collective security.
Kirishima, you're on thin ice as it is.
Doc, I've trusted you with my life.

Fields.DialogueText: Never, Captain. I know what's at stake.
I swear, Kanchou, I'd never hide anything from you or the Belle.
Don't pull that on me. I can't answer for the boy going sightseeing.
No, indeed.
I certainly hope not.
I'm sure you do.
You probably know how little that means.
Granted. But you've certainly known him longest. You were on a boat together even before this all started.
The Captain exits the room...
You're telling me that it's not actually a compass?
Isn't it? I mean... look at it.
I did, Kanchou. From every angle, at every time of day, at every temperature...
All right, we're shoving off. Montevideo is our next stop.
If you say so.
I do say so. We can't wait around for someone who may not even be coming back.
You think Lugin's gone for good?

Fields.MenuText: I don't know what I think.
Was it something I said?
If he knows what's good for him.

Fields.DialogueText: Maybe he always did.
Nah. Lugin's bigger than that. He wouldn't leave just because of hurt feelings.
But the course of the war doesn't turn on just one person.
Doesn't it?
Don't give me that, Enoch. I'm not the only one the Belles get along with.
Sure. But the less time we spend auditioning for savior of humanity, the better.
Can't blame him, in a sense.
Not morally, perhaps. Legally... that's a different story.
Greener pastures?
Greener wallet, maybe.
Right. Any word on the compass?
Kirishima's been over it with a fine-toothed microscope. Doesn't respond to any stimuli she's been able to come up with. It's fixed on the south.
Brilliant. We blow up a cursed Belle and all we have to show for it is an opposite compass.
... Run that by me again.
It only points south, doesn't it?
Well, southish, but--
Kanchou! We need to head south-southwest! I have the bearing and everything--
Sounds like they're on to us.
Or she's on to them.
@BATTLE
Ie. Hai. Well, not really. The problem was on my end.
I was *convinced* that it was some kind of nefarious Morgana artifact.
And I mean *every* temperature. It won't burn, and Doc says I'm not allowed in cold storage anymore.
And for a week and a half you didn't think to just compare it to an actual compass.
I thought it'd be a bad influence or something. I don't know what I thought.
The point is that it doesn't point toward magnetic south.
It's not super clear on our current course, but once we tack west around Uruguay it should be obvious.
So what's it pointing at?
Well, the Morganas have tried to hold certain spots to repair in. But Enoch says they've only been regional in nature.
That is, they've only served small and temporary forces and operations. And what we've been able to decipher of Morgana chatter doesn't direct them to these positions.
So they've been exclusive clubs until now. You set it up and it's your scene.
But now they've got something bigger brewing.
But don't they have some kind of hive mind? Why would they need navigation tools?
Well, Belles don't have one.
If that makes sense.
No, it does. They're both cut off from... wherever they're from. Mostly.
This is how they interact with our world. So if they can read this thing, so can we.
Not that we'd want to.
Aug-- Cassel-ku-- san, uh--
Kapitän. You're going to- no. You're *not* going to want to listen to this.
Another berserk Belle?
Nein. It's a whole different flavor of disgusting. Find yourself a seat - it should start up again pretty soon.
I'm one of a few with nothing left to lose.
There's the alarm. Are we done here?
@BATTLE
"Another setback is feared in the waters around St. Helena."
"Civilian shipping between South America and Africa has ground to a halt. An attempt by a Royal Navy battle group to reestablish a route has ended in apparent carnage."
"Those who love life are invited to hear the voices of the upstarts in question."
I didn't bother transcribing what followed.
Nor should you have.
"Let the seas rest. Let your people thrive. Let your world move on. Yours always, Rosa Maria."
That's how she signs off every broadcast.
Uruguayan, Argentine, and Brazilian intelligence have all been slapping down broadcast stations wherever they can find them, but they've never been able to collar the woman herself.
People actually listen to this?
By some accounts, it's in the top ten broadcasts in the region.
August, I know what you're going to say, but I have to ask--
You'll only pry me out of that radio room when I'm dead.

Fields.MenuText: I'm worried I might have to.

Fields.DialogueText: I didn't choose this, Kapitän, any more than you chose your command.

Fields.MenuText: I'm starting to think Lugin should have taken you carousing.
I reserve the right to enforce leave, August.

Fields.DialogueText: As far as I'm concerned, he's right where he belongs.
And who enforces it for you?
That's none of your concern.
I only command our forces against the Morganas. You have to listen to them.
Do you think you're the only radioman in the fleet?
So should we all be.
You're done the minute we see anything else like Santa Catarina.
Clock's ticking.
... It's worse than I thought.
"Estamos rodeados!"
"No puedo oir Montevideo!"
"Suffer. It's no less than you deserve."
"Yes, you, listening in."
Must you torture yourself so?
Would you like to take over my shift?
You know...
Scheisse!
If I were an evil ship spirit, I'd say that sort of thing as a matter of course.
It costs me nothing if I scare a human who happens to be listening.
That had occurred to me.
Non. But I will insist on you taking coffee.
It's not drugged, is it? I wouldn't put it past the Captain to enlist our medical staff against me.
Do you hear yourself? Not everything's a battle.
Danke. Just put it next to Savary's?
August, I brought coffee if--
Bonsoir, Kirishima.
Savary-san.
... Enjoy.
Not everything's a battle.
Well, now you've done it.
I've checked the charts. It's somewhere in the middle of the Weddell Sea.
As luck would have it, there's a beef mogul in the capital who's willing to put our passengers up in an old company town.
There's Montevideo.
And there's the Morganas.
I thought they were easing up around here.
They haven't chanced the River Plate since December. Apparently Paranoia screwed up that bad.
But they still make the occasional pass out where the water's blue.
Business as usual, then.
For now. There's some things that just don't add up... yet.
@BATTLE
All right, let's review. We've got a compass that points to *something.*
Any Morgana chatter on that, August?
I've caught snatches of their conversation after battles. Nothing intelligible, but there are certain consistent bits.
And the survivors all tacked south, per the reconnaissance we've been able to look at.
Despite previous raids on the Brazilian coast for materiel. Those have fallen off lately.
But I've seen them patched up regardless. So they're willing to stretch their reserves when possible for... some kind of destination.
Score one for De Ruyter.
But if there's a facility or something in Antarctica, shouldn't there be more Morgana activity in this region?
Unless they've been deliberately laying low.
At our own peril.

Fields.MenuText: All the more reason that we should be rooting them out of wherever they're setting up shop.

Fields.DialogueText: The way I see it, we signed up to protect humanity. Not to dust off some glaciers.

Fields.MenuText: Do we know any Belles studying the area?
Kirishima, has that compass behaved itself?

Fields.DialogueText: Graf Spee has a working relationship with some German liaisons operating out of Buenos Aires.
It stays where I put it and doesn't scream.
Isn't that what we signed up for?
But if they're massing there--
Savary. Any word from your Uruguayans?
And they call *us* pests.
They've reported some opportunistic raids downcountry, but nothing serious since Tierra del Fuego in November.
Morganas or Germans?
Ja.
I suppose that's progress.
He's in talks with the Intendant to arrange an escort inland from Montevideo.
Forty acres, eh?
In exchange for special INPF protection for the River Plate. Just for the duration of the war.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I'm sure we can shake out the details as that becomes relevant.

Fields.DialogueText: No word on Lugin, I take it?
None. Although...
There has been a development on that front. Maybe.
"Maybe?"
Yeoman Miller's missing too.
All right, have I failed to notice anyone else deserting?
Well--
I'd advise you not to answer that.
I think I can answer any questions I want.
Just advice, Mademoiselle.
Why are you making that sound so condescending? Aren't we pretty much the same age?
I'd forgive anyone the confusion.
Well, looks like it's back to the radio.
Wait--
August--
I'll check up on him later. Does anyone have anything to add?
Nothing.
Well, meeting adjourned, I suppose.
While we're on the subject of advice, Cap... if I were you, I'd put that man on a lifeboat with a fifth of Doc's moonshine.
What moonshine?
Ask van Geffen. She'll talk your ear off about it...

Fields.MenuText: The Intendant also had a gift for us, I understand. Some Morgana thing they found in the Rio?

Fields.DialogueText: An ASDIC from one of Paranoia's group. She must have dropped it in the mud when Spee slapped her down.
One Morgana artifact on board is quite enough.
It's docile so far, at least. Anything would be with a 24-hour flamethrower detail.
Scintillating. Any word on Lugin?
Neither did I. But I peeked at Enoch's De Ruyter stuff the other day and decided we needed one.
Not the kind I'm developing.
Kapitän.
August. How's--
Sayako. Good work.
I know that look.
He seemed focused.
More than that. I recognize that look from Europe.
It's his "one wrong move and everything goes to hell and it's my fault" look.
@BATTLE
I never took you for a photographer.
It was really nice of the Belle to let me set up a darkroom in here.

Fields.MenuText: Classified INPF documents?

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, come on, Kanchou. You were going to tell us about it at yesterday's meeting anyway.

Fields.MenuText: What have you found out?

Fields.DialogueText: Nothing we don't already know. But that's good. It means we're on the right track.

Fields.MenuText: You peeked or he leaked?

Fields.DialogueText: I asked him really nicely and batted my eyelashes. He won't admit it, but he likes that.
Belles do that with you, don't they?
Yes, but I'm their commanding officer.
All the more reason!
The challenges of rank. Well, what have you found out?
Maybe, but it's unethical.
So?
It turned out fine, but just put someone like Lugin in your shoes.
Who do you think I learned photography from?
He takes Morgana pictures too?
Uh--
They're really not easy to get, either, so they go for a hefty chunk of change. This one shot of Corruption with her back turned was--
What *else* have we learned?
Almost... almost... there. See this one? Notice the big number 10 on this Cowardice?
Wait a minute. That looks...
I didn't know Morganas identified each other by number.
They don't. See, it shows up on Malice... Mistrust... there it is on Treason...
Kanchou?
That's from Mato Grosso. The other Pará-class that Brazil lost in January.
Let me handle it, Sayako.
So there *is* some sort of facility churning out parts for repairs.
Careful! You'll expose the--
Oh. A-- Cassel-san, I--
No time, Kapitän. Urgent from Command. And we've got Nixen closing.
That's what he said...
You sure you want to talk to the man who killed a Belle?
So Sayako was right about the spiky planes in the Baltic.
Not spiky, Kapitän. Spiny.
Those look like... insects.
We've only seen a scout variety thus far. RAF's taken to calling them "picket flies."
Any idea where they've come from?
You'll find this interesting, Kapitän. A Swedish patrol picked up a Sin on their radio. Here's a transcript from a close encounter off Bornholm.
"Sin: Eww, those things make my skin crawl. Why can't she play with her own toys?"
"Well, while they're away, you and I can play..."
The rest was wisely redacted.

Fields.MenuText: I assume "she" is a new Morgana.
Never a dull moment with Sin, at least.
I don't suppose you could wire them for the rest. Research, you know.

Fields.DialogueText: We can only assume.
Then what Santa Catarina said about bugs...
Imagine being chased through a forest by a bear in the dead of night, Kapitän.
Now imagine that bear wants to have its horrible way with you.
All right, you've made your point.
You find your own smut, Kapitän.
No, I meant-- never mind.
I didn't want to commit to the idea right away. Not until it was staring me in the face.
I used to dream, Kapitän.
August?
You could look out over the ocean and wonder what was on the other side, once upon a time. And even here in the modern world, you can look to its depths... to the stars...
You could imagine the sheer scale of things and be awed at how small you were within them.
Instead of holding your breath every time you tune in, or turn a page...
Wondering if your next hypothesis was a deadly trap. If the next question you asked would lead you to madness, or worse.
Tut mir leid, Kapitän. But surely you understand... it's to the point where you don't want to believe something unless it's staring you right in the face.
I hate to interrupt, but--
Is... now a bad time?
No, actually. August was just asking after you.
Oh! Well...
But it'll have to wait. Stations, everyone!
@BATTLE
So. How are--
So.
That's not how I would have put it.
The minute we dance around it is the minute the Nixen come back for more.
Cassel... August-kun, I don't blame you for Santa Catarina.
You haven't been reading the newspapers, have you?
Ie, I've been a little busy. Research.
Well, Brazil's calling for the Kapitän's head.
There was nothing we could do for her. August, you've seen the planes - you were right about everything.
Do you know how much I hate being right lately?
Imagine you had to listen to the Morganas day in and day out.
Imagine you heard a Belle suffering at their hands, and there was nothing you could do.
And the Kapitän's responsibility is to be blamed for everything that follows from that. You saw how that played out for Constitution.
That's Kanchou's problem.
I could have not passed it along.
And then we wouldn't be having this conversation. And in case you hadn't noticed, I like talking to you.
Sayako.
August-kun...
You of all people should understand being caught between two terrible decisions.
What--
When you told Bertie to scout out False Hope--
You're saying I'm responsible for his death?
In some small way we--
Urusai!
You don't think I know how it feels to be powerless? To be in a war I didn't ask for?
I learn about the Kami, about the Funayūrei, because we're dead if we don't. But somewhere along the way, it dawned on me that they're *really cool.*
How may opportunities do you get to talk to a machine? To fight the embodiment of disease, or sin, or despair?
I don't pretend the Funayūrei don't scare me. But the things I spend my life working on are coming to life to teach *me* how to scare *them.*
So I listen, and I learn, and sure, sometimes I mourn.
But I don't... I don't *keep* mourning! Least of all for shit that hasn't happened yet! And how dare you try and drag me down there with you.
I don't need to. You'll get there soon enough.
And you'll really, really wish you hadn't.
Am I interrupting--
Shut up!
Urusai!
Da, da, da, I know when I'm not needed. I'll give you lovebirds a minute alone, yes?
Was that--
Lugin-san, wait up!
@BATTLE
... You don't say.
I have it on good authority from a trawler crew in a bar in Porto Alegre that there is something ominous brewing down in the Weddell Sea.
You have three minutes to explain to me why I shouldn't send you back to Leningrad in that crate Sayako found the compass in.
Always setting exciting challenges! This is why I come back to you.
You've wasted five seconds.
Khorosho. It all started with our radioman's unfortunate run-in with demons.
His own? The ones we fight? A fascinating psychological question for another day.
January was hard on everyone, after all. But wait! Command rewards us with a vacation to the tropics.
Is that what you think this is?
Straight and narrow?
Pozhaluysta, Kapitan, you are running out the clock.
So after our narrow escape from dabbling in European geopolitics, I find myself more adrift than usual, among people who also find themselves adrift.
We all have pieces of a vaguely Morgana-shaped puzzle, but we are too wrapped up in our various interpersonal conflicts and revelries to fit them together.
"Revelries?"
And then Savary happens to introduce me to a new friend of hers who, as luck would have it, is an old friend of mine from Baku.

Fields.MenuText: Savary's involved in this nonsense?
Get to the point.
And you expect me to believe that an old buddy from Azerbaijan happened to be kicking around Natal.

Fields.DialogueText: Nyet, Kapitan, I hardly believed it myself!
Konechno. Summing up, we went out drinking, for as luck would have it we arrived in Brazil during Carnival.
Why, it could never have happened without her wise counsel! You might say she keeps me on the straight and narrow.
How did you know this person?
From a morning run, believe it or not. You see, he had a penchant for mathematics, and when I'd found him he'd fired a rifle over the Caspian.
He invited me to find the bullet on the other side where he'd calculated it would land, of course I took him up on this offer, and thus began a fascinating--
Leningrad, Orest.
Kapitan, if only you could have seen the sights! The samba, the fireworks, the costumes-- you should have seen the craftsmanship on the shipgirl outfits, the rigging alone... but I digress.
In a manner of speaking. But as luck would have it, that path led me directly to Carnival!
Our mutual friend introduced me to other friends, and we got talking, and then we got drinking...
And when the party dried up in one city, we moved to the next. And the next. And the next... meeting increasingly interesting and wealthy individuals along the way.
Your colleagues aren't exactly a representative sample.
Suffice it to say, Kapitan, that I have learned a great deal about conditions within our erstwhile host nation. And you need never again worry about your bourbon cabinet.
Then continue not to worry.
I don't keep one.
So for two weeks you've been AWOL, carousing in Brazil and following us down the coast, only to meet up with us again in Montevideo.
And to show for it you have a booze hookup for which you arranged... I don't even want to contemplate it.
Never you worry about that, Kapitan. If you judge someone by what newspapers say about them, you'll look at them completely upside down. My colleagues know this.
Once I mentioned your name, Kapitan, the cachaça flowed like spring snowmelt.
Do you realize how this looks?
We already have a reputation for interfering in the affairs of the nations we're sworn to protect, motive be damned.
Now the Brazilian newspapers are baying for my head because we killed one of their Belles, the transcript exonerating us is classified, and I'm sending my people inland to party.
Anyway, you've wasted enough of our time. This time next week--
Make it quick.
Only one more thing, Kapitan! One last bit of information, and then you may do what you like with me.
Why, they barely escaped with their lives! Some facility or other rising out of the freezing waves.
Naturally they looked at me like I was crazy when I asked for coordinates.
We can litigate that another time. The others are going to want to hear this.
Miss you? Hell, I was dead set on taking you out myself if the Morganas didn't.
Good talk.
@BATTLE
Enoch! Did you miss me?
Orest.
I figured you'd be back by the time we left Brazilian waters. You have any idea what a nightmare it's been covering for you?
Scarcely more nightmarish than usual. Why do you think I spent the extra day wooing that meat baron in Montevideo?
That was you? I thought Savary had that conversation.
And who do you think landed her the appointment?
Heh. You know I've made it my policy not to ask how you do these things.
The strongest friendships are built upon such foundations.
Sure. And I know Doc and the others are going to be over the moon.
A very shiny moon, if you catch my meaning.
For sure. But look, you've missed... a lot.
Sayako isn't talking to August. August isn't talking to anyone.
There's some kind of Morgana nonsense going on near Antarctica, and I think finding out what it is is going to be the key to keeping this ship together.
Savary's getting restless and the docs are at each other's throats again now that there aren't two hundred-odd sneezing refugees to look after.
Silly as this may sound, I think we're all feeling a little unmoored with the major fronts so far away. Hell, even I'm getting a little homesick.
How quickly we grow used to playing the hero, eh?
Great talk.
Did they really not notice I was missing?
Tradeoffs, my accomplice, tradeoffs. You'll get out of the brig before I do.
When you happen to be around for the end of the world, you get antsy while your back's turned.
Well, it seems to be waiting around near Antarctica with a knife for that very back.
That trawler crew give you any idea what it's made of?
It's funny, Enoch. I might never have made conversation if I hadn't noticed a certain conversation piece on their table.
Wouldn't you know it - they had a compass that only pointed south. Ish.
Good lord. You don't mean they had a Morgana... whatever it is... among all those people?
Worry not. They'd found it in a ship that had been run aground and burned. And sprinkled with holy water, I can only assume.
Whatever that thing is that Sayako has been puzzling over, rest assured that it's... lost its spark. Expired. Probably.
And one assumes they were headed south to figure the flint that struck that spark.
Well, our crewmates are going to appreciate the insight. August should rest a little easier knowing he isn't totally crazy.
Oh, he is. In a few ways. Some of them are almost the right ones.
I'll pass that along while you're locked in here.
Good to have you back.
Wouldn't miss it for the world.
Oh, speaking of. You're coming to the first meeting, right? Wednesday?
Just until we can untangle what the hell he's been up to.
You're sure he needs to be locked up down here?
Yes, Captain.
Until then, while you're on shift, don't let him out of your sight.
The Captain gives them both an inscrutable look, and then leaves the scene...
What do you have for headaches, Doc?
Start with aspirin. But go easy. I'm still replenishing my stock from the big refugee ride.
Well, it depends. The INPF hasn't hammered out substance regulations.
Let's assume I'm not feeling adventurous.
@BATTLE
... Tulips.
You're a lifesaver, Doc.
Definitionally.
You're also a liar.
Finally someone says it.
Your opinion's warranted. There's your lie.
There's no way Orest could have disappeared for as long as he did without a man on the inside.
You can't prove anything.
I don't need to. Orest spilled the beans.
One too heavy for our resident teetotaler to lift.

Fields.MenuText: Is this the sort of thing you people do for fun?
Why?
Of course you realize that the Captain gets a cut.

Fields.DialogueText: Well, you're not far off the mark.
Oh, come now. Surely Lugin told you *why* we all went in on the big conspiracy.
I'm a long way from home. My housemate keeps these. And one or two here and there makes her feel just that little bit closer.
It helps that she lives far from any body of water bigger than a canal.
That was the general idea, yes. We just didn't expect you to catch on until we could say "surprise."
Apparently, your price is a case of cachaça.
Based on what everyone ordered, I can make an inference.
Fancy drinks... sheet music... you could have just requisitioned all this, you know.
And leave a paper trail for the Morganas to crash the party with? Never!
You know, Orest said something similar. The Morganas would get me and use the knowledge against all of you, or something.
I told you that was a ludicrous excuse.
Well, maybe we needed a little ludicrosity around the house.
We've never been further from the action, Captain. But you wouldn't know it to speak to any of us.
And one fine day, while Savary was down here putting together her little war orphan scrapbook, she decided enough was enough.
The minute we got them to safety, we'd have space for a dance floor of sorts. And some free cots, in case the relaxation got out of hand.
Of?
You're invited to our first meeting, incidentally.
We were going to wait until Lugin got back to pick a name for our little get-togethers.
Well, I suppose it's no stranger than anything the Belles get up to.
This is all above board, I take it?
It's Lugin, Captain. The boards are somewhere in the clouds with Kirishima's head.
All right. But this doesn't interfere with the mission, you hear? The others put together something major brewing--
--South of the Falklands.
Right. And now we've got independent confirmation of what we suspected.
Looks like Europe will have to wait. Well, I'd better see about sorting some inventory... old and new.
I'm surprised you were in on it.
What was yours?
Oh, don't be. Everyone has a price.
God only knows where Lugin found them in Brazil. But there they were, and I had to have them.
Simple tastes?
For a few days I was sure that whatever Morgana *thing* she was dealing with was baiting us. Influencing her. Manufacturing this sacrifice we're coming to terms with.
Maybe I should call you Overthinker-kun.
Look. Whatever the compass represented... whatever it did... it did to Santa Catarina. And then it was done. And we're headed south now to put a stop to it. That's what matters.
@BATTLE
Desired? Recalled? Furtively whispered of? Well, whatever you're doing, there I am.
Waiting on a friend.
A happy coincidence. So am I.
Let's see what this manifest has in store...
... Would one of those crates happen to be full of cachaça?
... Were we both sold the same contraband?
All right, everyone is to remain in port while we refuel and repair. That's all Buenos Aires has cleared us for.
Neutrality?
Neutrality. Brazil's been working closely with the United States, but Argentina's doing their best to stay out of the war.
Last I heard, they were more focused on reopening their trans-Atlantic trade. If you think Uruguay's beef industry has it bad...
Well, it seems to me that pledging support to the INPF would do wonders on that front.
It would also make them a target, which I for one understand. There's been markedly less Morgana activity between here and the Falklands for the past several weeks.
... Oh, hell. Hold on. The Belle's arguing with our neighbors. I'm going to go break it up.
Who are we docked between?
Brits to our left, Nazis to our right. That ain't a crossfire I fancy. Well, I think I'll get some shuteye.
Have you got the key to--
Lugin, yep. Business?
We've both got last shipment. I'll bring him right back.
Sure was nice of the Belle to kick up some dust.
*yawn* Ohayo. Is Lugin-san out of the brig yet?
Not officially.
So, yes.
He's a bad influence on you.
Funny. He said your mutual friend was a bad influence on you.
Dieu merci. Do be gentle with August in the meantime.
I'm always-- I mean--
Nothing personal. He's just... delicate.
So.
So.
Want to talk about Friday?
No. But I understand.
I was so caught up in what happened - in my role in what happened - that I didn't consider what didn't. Happen, I mean.
Well, Lugin-san said there was another compass.
And it too was depowered.
Oh, good, he talked to you too.
I... don't know what I expected. I thought at first that perhaps I might break his nose for fleeing the front. But he turned out to be right where he needed to be.
Just... differently than I'd decided.
I'm sorry. I blamed you for something that was out of your hands.
I blamed myself at first.
Do you miss it? Carousing on land?
Like you'd miss a state-mandated vacation. One's labor power must be reproduced, but if you spent all your time reproducing you'd be a rabbit.
And so I go where I am needed.
But we wouldn't know what we know without False Hope. Without Bertie... investigating. It'd be a different war. Harder, probably.
So the things we've done or not done to win it... it's not about blame. And we can't do them alone.
There was... a shadow in her voice. Santa Catarina.
But that doesn't make sense. Why would she let the sailors go? Why would she give us the compass?
I got there eventually.
Heh. I've been called worse things.
And you're comfortable with that decision.
Beyond comfy. I made it long before you and I got busy on those explosives.
I-- that is, we--
Lugin-san told me about them. Gotta run. Stations. We'll talk.
We will indeed.
Ah! And that must be--
The friend in question! We will be in wine and cheeses through June!
How perplexing. It would seem we have similar tastes.
And in that cooler--
Venison.
Eighty pounds of it.
Next time you go missing, let's keep in touch.
Next time I go missing, I'll have a very close look at your address book.
The Captain withdraws in a hurry.
Just while things are quiet, Kapitän.
Your words, Captain. "Don't let him out of your sight."
This might be our longest uninterrupted cruise yet.
What do you call that Morg fleet over there?
A distraction.
@BATTLE
Confident, ain't we?
I don't know. I get the feeling we're distracting them.
... And there's one thing I still don't get.
This about the compass?
Sort of. The Baltic powers keep reporting those bug planes that no Morgana has yet claimed.
And we've had two such compasses turn up, both of which resulted in the death of the ship in question.

Fields.MenuText: We're positive those compasses only point south?

Fields.DialogueText: Sayako and I have been over ours every which way from Sunday. If it were some kind of time bomb, it'd have one hell of a fuse.

Fields.MenuText: Do we know if the trawler Lugin mentioned had a Belle?
So perhaps they're cursed.

Fields.DialogueText: Lugin said she did. I... don't like to think about it. But it sounds like the crew made the right choice when they found their compass.
I won't pretend to know where Santa Catarina got her hands on one. But if you take what Lugin said about that trawler crew and add the two up...
Then maybe the compass was pointing someone in *their* direction.
Wouldn't be the first we've heard of cursed objects.
They're not cursed.
Santa Catarina tell you that?
She didn't need to. A curse is magic, and there's no such thing as magic.
Some of our Belles would disagree.
Some of our Belles aren't all there.
Don't let them hear you say that. Walk with us.
I don't mean to be rude. I've just been doing some thinking.
Away from the radio. That's good.
Excuses, excuses. Good to have you tonight, August.
I reserve the right to be contemplative. But just hear me out.
Certain Belles allude to there being something beyond all this. A world of their own, or that built them.
The older ones - Aurora, Schleswig-Holstein, Constitution especially - had some kind of connection, or instinct.
And then there are the Morganas. God only knows what they're doing, but they come from somewhere too. They recognize what's theirs and not theirs. That's Sin with the planes.
Magic doesn't have to make sense. It's forcing things to act as they otherwise wouldn't.
I believe there are rules governing all of this. Unfair rules, maybe. But they make sense if only we can read them.
You seem confident that we can.
"We" is the operative word.
Heh. About time. Now, come on. The others are getting restless.
Ah, the guest of honor! Drink this, Captain. Doctor's orders.
Welcome to the club, Kapitan!
Lugin, what the--
No need to thank me. I am doing what you pay me to.
I don't remember letting you out of the brig.
He's under lock and key, Capitaine. Sentenced to tend bar until we're tired.
They handcuffed me to this door we're using as a bar, you see.
And what do we do with doors?
We knock!
Doc's idea, Cap. We're in hostile waters--
You might say that all waters are hostile waters.
-- and it's enough to drive a body mad. Unless once in a while you can kick back and damn it all.
Thus was born the Damn-It-All Club!
Open to all souls in need of one balm or another. And I know balms.
Especially the ones that come in a bottle and are served with limes.
Well, it's not exactly regulation...
But neither is spiriting hundreds of Jews across the sea.
Two different things.
And yet both are good for the soul. Bartender!
Once you see something, you never let it go. I admire that about you, Kirishima. It's something I see in him too.
Come on before we're both killed.
@BATTLE
It's been altogether too quiet.
Maybe if we get *really* lucky, we'll find another beacon.
Is that what you and Enoch are calling the compass now?
What else could it have been? It was calling to someone. Something. August and Lugin said so. Right, August-kun?
Aren't you and August...?
I... don't know. Is it important to you?
The welfare of my crew is my business.
Nice Kanchou impersonation. Is it important to you?
"Important" important?
I'm taking the silence in stride.
Mm. I thought you'd be angrier at Lugin.
What for?
Gallivanting through South America on a party tour?
You're the ship's unofficial diplomat. Do you have any idea how exhausting his tour must have been?
Making contacts, making deals, racing over land to keep up with us... I'm surprised he hasn't slept through these past few days.
And you?
If we're being honest... no. I've been catching up on my reading.
None of your usual transcripts, I hope.
Rosa Maria stuff. The propagandist to the Nixen.
Must you do this to yourself?
I did something different. I tried looking at her broadcasts as... well, literature. Looking for commonalities, tropes... that sort of thing.
And what did you find?
That penchant she has for playing the voices of human victims... it's using us against us.
It's... difficult to listen to them and not feel responsible.
I play at moving mountains with a word in the right ear, August. But you're only responsible for what *you're* responsible for.
"Let your world move on."
Hmm?
I don't know. Maybe I don't have to.
Near as either of us can tell. I think I'd better turn in, though. It's getting a bit chilly...
One step at a time.
What's that supposed to mean?
I know I'm not the only one who brings him coffee when the night gets slow and lonely.
But he takes it with one and a half sugars, not two.
Wait, how did you--
We're getting a transmission, Captain. August says it's the unknown frequency.

Fields.MenuText: Let it go. We move forward no matter what they say.
And they want to parley?
So tell them to scuttle themselves.

Fields.DialogueText: They want to say something, Captain.
Probably for the best. You sure?
That'd probably just make them angry.
I reserve the right to cut it. Especially if it's another broadcast like Lagos.
Um... hello? Is this thing on?
This is the First Captain of the INPF. Identify yourself or we will open fire.
They've baited us this far. We don't need to know anything that they haven't told us.
Eep! It's the Captain!
Cowardice.
Hey, uh, so... the other girls wanted me to tell you that you should *really* not come any farther south if you know what's good for you.
Angry enough to destroy the world?
Point taken.
Your warning is hereby acknowledged and disregarded.
Oh, that's bad, isn't it? Well... okay. But it's really, really scary down here. I mean it!
Like, seriously, you should probably just turn around and let us keep doing our thing? Okay? Please?
Cut the transmission and fire.
Damn it! Someone get a bead on that!
The Belle's on it! I'm shifting course twenty to the east.
@BATTLE
We're due west of the Falklands. If you look over there, you can just see them.
Any word from Stanley, August?
Dark clouds to the south. That pattern's been holding for the last month or so.
Not enough inclement weather to qualify as a maelstrom, but--
*BOOM*
What do we hear from Stanley?
The Brits have a patrol out, but we're going to have to hold on for at least two hours.
Hey! Captain! Did you not listen to me?
We start as we mean to go on.
Looks like they're backing off.
Finally. I was beginning to think we'd never see the end of them.

Fields.MenuText: Look how we handled them here, though. You don't think we can keep it up?
You're telling me. Stanley would have been in trouble if we hadn't arrived.
I want to at least get a look at it.

Fields.DialogueText: I didn't think they'd mass this far up, Kanchou.
I did.
Insider information, Radio-kun?
Educated guess. We're close to the edge of human settlement. I doubt they'd wait around for us to get to whatever they're building in the Weddell Sea.
Call me defeatist, Captain, but we might not want to take it on without backup.
If this is the sort of force they're willing to project from... whatever's down there, God only knows what we might find if we get to it.
Right place, right time, at least.
Famous last words.
We've had a few of those, haven't we?
I'm keeping a list. It should be entertaining reading once we're done.
He sure knows a lot that he isn't telling us.
That's how He works.
I feel better about listening to them already.
Just don't start talking back.
Unless it's to insult. Morale initiative and all that.
Transmission from Stanley, by the way. They want to know if you'd like a thank-you present.
Quiet, everyone. We've got another transmission.
Hey, this is the humans, right? The special ones?
Is that one of them?
Cowardice. We've spoken.
So, uh... how about that skirmish, huh?
Your sisters tried to raze Stanley to the ground, you feathered fu--
We know what you're up to in the Weddell Sea.
Oh, *that's* what you guys call it now. Well... we're kind of using it.
Ow! I wasn't going to tell them!
... Um. Yeah. Could y'all just... stay away? You keep getting closer aannnd it's honestly creeping me out.
Ahem. Consider yourself crept.
The hell is she on about?
Eep! Okay, signing off now, bye!
She's scared of her own wake, isn't she? Almost makes you feel sorry for her.
That's how they get you.
Would this present happen to be military in nature?
Another hunk of Nixe junk. It's a... duck of some description. Ugly little brass thing that quacks when danger is near.

Fields.MenuText: Very well. But I don't want anyone alone with it for more than an hour.

Fields.DialogueText: And I imagine they'd be quite glad to be rid of it.
They assured me it was rigorously reverse-engineered. It doesn't even bite anymore.

Fields.MenuText: Well, we're not dwelling on this thing either. Vane's got a whole world to use as a warehouse of horrors.

Fields.DialogueText: No feeding necessary, at least. I'm told it stays in small bodies of water and is reasonably polite about it.
I'll let them know we're full up on bath toys.
Murderous toy animal... I sense Vane's hand in this.
There was a Sloth that sleepwalked straight into a mine. Blew her quarters right open. There was a bathtub, and... well. Other things best not dwelt on.
All right. I see something gray.
Mhm. Like grubby cobblestones, perhaps?
I hadn't thought about it, but that is an apt simile.
Wet and heaving, I imagine.
Well, now you're just being crude.
Because it sounds like you're describing the ocean.
Chert. "Surely she would not go for the obvious choice," I thought to myself.
Thrice in a row?
How likely is that, really?
Has it escaped your notice that there's nothing else around for miles?
I sense you are not entertained by my wry commentary on our isolation.
There's nobody to talk to.
And I suppose I am a figment of your imagination.
Perhaps you are.
On that we can agree.
We've offloaded the refugees. I've taken statements from crew in every part of the ship. And August, try as he might, still refuses to let me look at those radio transcripts.
Bon. Alone without my thoughts.
Ah, Savary! Are you having as tedious a morning as I?
*SIGH*
Shall we while away the time with a game, Orest?
I can think of worse ways to while.
Magnifique. I see something gray.
Is it that ominous shape on the horizon?
De quelle fo--
*BOOM*
A point for me!
@BATTLE
Good eye earlier, Orest.
What can I say? Savary inspires me.
I'm sure I'm not the only one who noticed that this battle was... lighter?

Fields.MenuText: Maybe I should have you and Lugin on watch more often.
It was a small escort force, after all.
We got lucky.

Fields.DialogueText: I do need a project, but... perhaps on a nicer day.
They haven't usually done that, have they?
It takes preparation to seize upon luck, Kapitan. Do you know, I once missed my train from Astrakhan to Stalingrad, but there was a tractor just sitting there--
I don't like it.
Blunt, but I respect your preference.
No, I'm talking about the engagement.
Generally the Rusalki have transported their ill-gotten gains themselves.
But that only takes you so far.
Too true, too true.
So we're seeing... a dedicated Morgana convoy?
Not all of them fought, did you notice? Some of them were determined to haul south.
Well, we can't pick the weather.
The only ones in that business are unfortunately our Belle's uglier cousins.
There's something bothering me about what you said, Savary. It *was* a light force that fought back.
Most of the rest fled south. Like they were hauling something somewhere.
That *is* new. And it suggests we're heading into something much bigger than us.
That hasn't stopped us before.
No. But we're going to have to take it slow. I'll see if I can't get some eyes in the sky...
What do you see?
More and more fog. What do you hear?
More and more noise. But it *is* noise, at least.
How do you mean?
It's not directed at us, specifically. I'm picking up the usual screams and splatters, natürlich, but mostly their blasted code... numbers, occasionally...
All the hallmarks of a routine operation, in other words. Admission, acknowledgement, orders... that sort of thing.
One assumes. And yet--
Holy shit.
Enoch?
We're heaving to. No closer. Look at that.
*whistle* I see what you mean. It's like... like a wall of them.
We're gonna need to contact Cape Town and Wellington. Something tells me South America ain't the only route keeping that mess afloat.
@BATTLE
There. 315. They're breaking away.
At least they ain't all coming for us.
That just means there's something worth guarding.
Any news from the air?
We sent out two planes. One made it back.
Hell.
We heard him, didn't we, August?
Insect planes, Kapitän. Just like the Kattegat.
Ugh. I hate bugs.
Even plane bugs?
Too little plane, too much bug.
So. We've got a wall of Nixen a few hundred kilometers in length and something horrible and semi-permanent operating to the south.
