Now, the other plane happened to dodge that patrol. He claimed that we've got Morganas from horizon to horizon. If what we're hearing is accurate...
They've set up a line from Elephant Island to the South Orkneys.

Fields.MenuText: I suppose that compass has run its course.
We're going to have to come at this with a much bigger force.
Any word on the facility itself?

Fields.DialogueText: I think it's worth keeping, Kanchou. It's doing more for us than it is for them at this point.
Agreed. Perhaps banishing us down here was a happy accident for the INPF after all.
None. It's farther than we can see. No doubt in the middle of some heinous ice, this time of year.
For one thing, its whispers help me sleep.
That isn't funny.
It's a little funny.
All right. In my opinion, this is now a reconnaissance mission.
We're wheeling west and gathering as much intel as we can on this... wall.
Then it's back up to the Panama Canal.
From what I've been hearing about mysterious outbreaks... let's say I don't exactly trust that quarantine.
You're concerned about it too.
We came all this way just to leave...
I'm glad to be out of here. Whatever's down there, there's nothing good we can do with the force we've got.
Still. To not even get a glimpse of whatever it was...
Don't worry yourself. I have a feeling it's coming to us.
Christ, it's cold out here.
Suppose that's one perk to serving out here. You can shop around for new ones.
@BATTLE
She's not gonna be mad, she's not gonna be mad, she's not gonna be mad, she's not gonna be--
Okay, Cowardice - ow - you did your job! Right?
Brisk, isn't it?
Suppose it's not much different to where you're from.
It's a little different.
Well, soon we'll be back up north. Might get a chance to visit home.
That may or may not be the best idea in the coming months.
Bad neighbors.
A bit worse than usual.
I still don't approve of the Doctor drinking.
Professional principle?
Half that, half that it gets under his skin.
Not that I'm opposed to your little club.
You'd be fighting a pretty grim battle if you were.
Back home it was easy to divide the work. Predictable. Less self-medication and illicit projects.
And he's a good doctor. Just... workaholic. One of these days he'll burn out.
Even cocaine stops helping eventually.
He didn't.
Suggested it, early on. The Captain shot it down.
Hmph. Obviously, what we say doesn't leave this stretch of deck. Especially that bit about him being a good doctor.
Obviously, it doesn't. But it looks like we ought to...
Bait the Captain south. That's all you had to do.
She didn't say *anything* about winning, right?
Cowardice, stand down. You're dead in the water.
Gah! Not the bridge!

Fields.MenuText: You're not far from your facility. We'll let the others tow you back if you tell us everything about it.

Fields.DialogueText: Oh, gosh, they *really* wouldn't like that.

Fields.MenuText: You're through. Scuttle yourself and we can keep this painless.
Any last words?

Fields.DialogueText: Uh... well, to tell you the truth...
Aww, why do you have to go there?
If we unpacked where *you'd* gone, we'd be here long enough for your friends to intercept us.
... I hate you!
Well, if that's that, then...
Consider yourself in our custody. You can do this the easy way or you can do it the hard way.
Uh... well... that is...
Where do you humans get off, swarming around like you own the place?
You build your stupid cities and you fight your stupid wars with your stupid weapons and then you act like *we're* the jerks for showing you up?
Excuse *us* for trying to win a game you're apparently determined to play forever and ever!
Kapitän, we're getting interference from-- gah!
You know, I talked to those German submarine people over at that elephant place and they weren't nearly as mean as--
The hell is she on about?
*BUZZZZZZ*
No, no, no, no, stupid, stupid, stupid, I said too much, I said *way* too much...
Captain, those bug planes!
Anti-air, now!
*BOOM*
I suppose that concludes our interrogation.
You heard the Morgana. We've got one more stop before we're out of here.
Brr. If I never come this far south again, it'll be too soon.
Layers, Kirishima. That is the key to weathering this latitude.
Breathe in that crisp winter air! There's something about it that makes the view clearer than anything.
We don't have this where I come from. The weather's always perfect.
Did there never come a point where that stopped helping, where you're from?
Oh, da, da, the chill always gets to your bones eventually. Always some unfortunate nose or ear to warm back up.
But you can always put on another jacket.
Well, the quicker we spot that submarine Cowardice was talking about, the better.
Not that I mind the environment, obviously. But what is the point of dithering for some fascist fish?
Oh, but think of the salvage, Lugin-san! Maybe we'll find ourselves a space heater.
It's not the salvage we should be worried about. I want any and all records pulled from that ship.
Cowardice said that the German sub crew was "nicer." And if that's the case, that's something other human fleets ought to know about.
You think they found another compass?
My gut says no. Think. Who else do we know who had a close encounter with Southern Ocean Morganas?
Santa Catarina.
And the nameless trawler.
Both of which were destroyed. Necessarily.
But *this* one made it all the way south to Elephant Island, apparently intact.
Strange, after the welcome we received near the Falklands.
So... did they follow a compass or something?
More to the point, what would it have done to them if they did?
Let's save that question for after we're in the clear.
@BATTLE
Well, I'll be. That rustbucket was telling the truth.
There! It's up on the rocks!

Fields.MenuText: Be careful. We don't know what she's leading us to.
Let's send out a salvage crew. Armed.
Place your bets. This is our last stop before we head back to the real world.

Fields.DialogueText: Something some other Morgana didn't want us knowing about.
Unless she wanted us to find out for ourselves.
Come ooon. This is Cowardice we're talking about, not Paranoia.
Such optimism, Kapitan. You think the Rusalki would have left us anything useful?
Ah, come on. I bet you could find something on there worth selling.
To a medical school, perhaps.
Kapitän, I request permission to accompany the salvage team.
I want five crew for a salvage team. Armed.
You can consider me shocked if anything's still alive on that hulk.
You mean "anyone?"
No.
Wait, August, you don't--
I do.
... If this is another dumb hero thing, I'll have the Belle leave you here. Don't think I wouldn't.
Sayako. We never would have made it here without all of us piecing this thing together.
Trust me, then, when I say that this is just curiosity. Call it... call it a stubborn streak.
Fine. But you're not allowed to die.
Sehr gut.
And if there's a dead Nazi to spit on in the bargain, so be it.
She's right about that last part. Now go get yourself ready.
Great! Just give me a gun and-
... Kanchou, August and I will *both* need guns.
No. Not this time. I don't begrudge the two of you your personal issues, but right now you're a distraction to each other and you'd be a distraction to whoever else we send.
Kirishima, you've got the most experience with-
Please. Please, Kapitän.
Yeah, we won't distract each other!
I already said, just one of you this time. August, can you even use a gun?
Ja. Enoch insisted I train.
If you go, you do what the Marines tell you. Right? No heroism, no - stop waving your hand, Kirishima.
But I'm good at raiding party stuff! You said it yourself! And I know more about Morgana tech, so if there's anything there I'll know better than anyone how to find it.
And can you honestly tell me you think Bertie wouldn't have had a better chance if I'd been with him on the False Hope?
I know I'm being a hypocrite, August, shut up.
... I didn't say anything.
Aber, Kapitän, can I talk to Sayako for just a minute?
You have the five minutes it'll take me to assemble the rest of the team. If you're not ready then, you both stay behind and I send Miller.
Danke.
... Rethinking those permissive fraternization policies?

Fields.MenuText: *sigh*

Fields.DialogueText: Four minutes and fifty seconds later...
Ja, Kapitän.

Fields.MenuText: You have no idea.
Better than having them sneak around behind our backs.

Fields.DialogueText: As for you...

Fields.MenuText: We've really got to get you some shore leave.
Next expedition into a sinister ghost ship is all yours.
If you ever want to talk about Bertie...

Fields.DialogueText: I know.
Huh. You're turning into my mother.
It's this damn job.
Again: salvage team. Five person. Armed.
So... nothing.
More or less as we expected. U-33 had no fuel, no munitions... even the galley was cleaned out.
So it really was a wild goose chase.
I was prepared to say that as well. But the Morganas *did* leave something behind. Well, a couple of things.
August recognized it right away. All the escape sets were there... except six.

Fields.MenuText: That only proves that six sailors left at some point.
Any signs of a Belle?
The Kriegsmarine won't be happy about this.

Fields.DialogueText: But *only* six? The rest were in working order. It doesn't add up.
Desertion, maybe. No telling where.
... None.
There was deformation on certain bulkhead frames. Pipes that looked like they'd been crushed in a human grip.
But, again... I don't know. People can do crazy things when they're under pressure.
No sign of a Belle having been there, either.
Not really a concern of mine, if we're being honest.
Ain't gonna be another Santa Catarina kerfuffle, though. You should see some of the pictures we took.
Too much weathering to implicate us, naturally.
That, and... it's odd.
Did August get his wish, at least?
No bodies.
No compass, either.
*sigh*
It's not like we've learned *nothing,* Cap. Whatever's sending stuff through up in the Baltic is sending stuff through down here.
And from what Orest and August tell us, it's had a rough time emerging further north than the frozen ass end of nowhere.
Well, it's not going to have that trouble forever. We can't be everywhere at once.
True enough. But neither can they, Captain.
They wouldn't need strong points otherwise.
Vanity's palace... that thing in Majorca that keeps coming back... whatever the hell they're building down there... it's all got to come down.
And we'll need icebreakers, flamethrowers... and a ton of DDT, by the look of things.
We'll have one hell of a story for Command when we get to Valparaíso.
Right. Valparaíso.
Seems the Morganas haven't seen enough of us.
You know what to do. Oh, Enoch...
Captain?
Where *is* August?
Orest said something about a closet. Probably catching a nap.
Much as I hate to wake him up...
@BATTLE
Not that gun in the shallows?
It hadn't been there long. Looked like it had been stripped from the vessel, then abandoned. Lack of space, maybe?
No sign of a Belle?
There's no telling.

Fields.MenuText: Forget it. We've dawdled enough in maelstrom-adjacent waters already.

Fields.DialogueText: No dispute there. Now, as for the other thing... well, it's more what we *didn't* find.

Fields.MenuText: Well, I guess the Belle can pick it  up. It's one less gun the Morganas can come back for.

Fields.DialogueText: The usual detail, Captain?
Swap every hour and kill anything that makes strange noises.
Terrible for the circumstances, yes. The curse of being widely read.
Right where I left you. My, this batch ought to sting.
I wondered where all the potatoes kept disappearing to.
Who put you in charge of the galley?
If someone had, you would have keeled over after breakfast.
Come on. You're more devious than that.
You're right. I would have paid that nice Russian boy to throw you overboard.
Long as we understand each other.
If you weren't so keen on sharing that still, I'd grind it up and feed it to you.
And my last words would be "you'll never find the antidote."
Well, look at the time. I'd better take cover.
We'll do each other a favor.
... Oh, by the way. How often do you water those tulips?
Weekly. Gets awfully dry down here.
We'll work out a schedule. Wouldn't want them to wilt. It's about the only color we got down here. Deal?
Deal.
... Thank you.
Don't mention it.
Never.
@BATTLE
All right, all right, my turn.
There was a destroyer called Maury, refitted down at the fac-tory...
They beefed up her stem and lifted her hem, and her stern was a similar story!
Divine poetry indeed! Who's next?

Fields.MenuText: Thank goodness none of this is getting recorded.

Fields.DialogueText: Are you kidding? This is going straight in the book.
What if I ordered you to leave me out of it?

Fields.MenuText: The Belle isn't in on this, is she?
There once was a warship called Texas...

Fields.DialogueText: I heard it was her idea.
In port after port she'd leave exes! Diff'rent stories they'd tell if 'twas heaven or hell, but ev'ryone knows how the--
*ALARM*
You'll forgive me if I choose to let that be a mystery.
Looks like the Belle heard you!
You told me this was her idea!
And you believed me?
That would go in the book, too.
*SOME TIME LATER*
So. The Antarctic Plan.
If you've got a better title, I'm all ears.
Non, non, it's perfect. Grabs the attention right away.
We've been so concerned about the population centers and strategic canals and such that we haven't even checked the dark corners of the earth.
It'll be a hell of a time trying to pull half the world's navies down to the bottom of the world. In no small part because there's similar nonsense going on at the top.
You know, this jaunt down to Antarctica has me thinking. Since there's little else to do but drink and sing bawdy songs.
Ever read South? Ernest Shackleton's book?
I've been trying not to think of *that* expedition since we set out.
He said that he and his men thought they saw a fourth man while they were hiking through South Georgia.
It was a hallucination.
Maybe. But it kept them going, in some small way. There's something to be said for having a shoulder to lean on. Even an illusory one.
If I ever start leaning on illusory shoulders, leave that out of the book. And have me committed.
You don't need to, Capitaine. We've got real spirits on our side.
And we're fighting evil spirits.
But the Morganas haven't got *us* on theirs.
Sounds like Doc's perfected his recipe.
I don't know about you, Capitaine, but I find both of those things comforting in the extreme.
Well. What's a strong drink without a little burn?
What indeed, Savary. What indeed.
